The latest news about the saga of Juliana Sgrena's ill-fated car ride after being released by kidnappers: 
 
 http://www.washtimes.com/world/20050307-120131-5769r.htm 
 
 It is being reported the Italians may have kept the US in the dark about a secret deal to pay ransom to the kidnappers. It claims the deal would have been nixed had the US known. President Bush has called for a probe. What a "probe" is in diplomacy-speak I don't know. 
 
 I'm going to make two fearless predictions:
 
 This story is going to die quickly. I believe it's quite plausible the release of the journalist was because of a payoff. I think the entire story is too embarassing and too hush-hush for us to ever know what really transpired. It will never come to a full-blown investigation. Neither side wants the strain that is inevitable in the coalition. 
 
 Efforts to kidnap more Italians will increase. The precedent had already been set with a previous incident mentioned in the article, showing the Italians will negotiate with cash. It's always a bad idea IMO.
 
 But then again, I may be all wrong.

 I think you are absolutely right, and I was thinking much of the same thing.
 
 There's no way the U.S. troops intended to shoot at Itallians in a car. They should have been informed.

I personally spoke with the soldiers who were manning that checkpoint including the ones who shot. The car flew past the stop signs and barbed wire that was placed out, they put a light on the car and it still continued at them, they fired warning shots, the car sped up at them, they shot to kill. That area was hit by 4 VBIED(Vehicle Born Improvised Explosive Devices{carbomb}) in the week leading up to that incedent. They are going to try to get these guys for murder now of the Italian agent/driver. Anyone else here about that?
